snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is The Independence Of The Judiciary Under Threat?
snippet.description:
There are many pillars in a democracy, those pillars support each other and become the edifice and framework that holds up and supports democracy. The legislature, the executive, the media, and the judiciary. But recent events have raised serious doubts over the functioning of these pillars as independent bodies, as four top Supreme Court Judges publicly highlighted some of the issues being faced by the judiciary. Allegations include the partiality displayed in the allocation of high profile cases, that junior judges are assigned to constitution benches, and biased decisions taken by the Chief Justices in the present and the past. This begs us to ask the question - is the freedom of our state institution under threat? Are bodies such as the Election Commission, the Judiciary and the media, being manipulated to achieve political ends? For all this and more, watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Budget Expectations 2017: Will PM Modi Go For A Robin Hood Budget?
snippet.description:
Two-and-half months have passed since demonetisation was announced. While a series of opinion polls have suggested considerable support for the government's bold move yet pundits have implied that the support is linked with Modi sarkaar's ability to give something 'back to people'. With the union budget to be presented on February 1, will the government go for a pro-poor, pro-farmer budget? Will it increase the outlay for social sector schemes? Will it bring in big-bang political measures such as targeted universal basic income for the poor? The larger question remains, how does the government plan to finance these schemes? Will there be a change in the tax rate? Will the government impose inheritance tax and bring back wealth tax or will it throw away fiscal consolidation into the winds? While experts agree that one direct outcome of demonetisation could be an increase in tax base however, it is too early to say that the expanding base will be able to generate the added revenue that will be needed to finance these programmes.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/budget-expectations-2017-will-modi-go-for-a-robin-hood-budget-447461?yt

snippet.description:
Tonight, on The Big Fight Road to 2019, we discuss the state grabbing all the headlines this week, West Bengal - a state which is absolutely vital to the BJP's Lok Sabha strategy in general elections with its 42 seats. Can the BJP pull off something spectacular like it did in the assembly elections in Tripura? We also talk to BJP's Bengal MP and Union Minister Babul Supriyo who says the centre is not misusing agencies and contrary to belief in many sections there is massive growing resentment against chief minister Mamata Banerjee.

snippet.title: Emergency Of 1975: Lessons In Democracy
snippet.description:
The Emergency of 1975 was discussed across political circles throughout this week. Questions have been asked about what the future holds, and whether such an event would ever happen in India again. Democratic institutions got top priority in the discussions. A panel discusses the Emergency at length and the lessons that people of the country must keep in mind from the event 43 years ago. To maintain eternal vigilance and ensure that democratic institutions remain safe have been the thrust of the discussions and debates.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Has India Finally Found Its #MeToo Moment?
snippet.description:
As more and more women share their accounts of sexual harassment and abuse exposing many big names in Bollywood, on The Big Fight, we debate -  is this Bollywood's watershed moment? With organisations like the Cine And TV Artistes Association investigating complaints and Producers Guild setting up a special committee to help #MeToo survivors, a change is surely visible but will it have far-reaching implications for workplaces and gender-sensitivity across the country? Is it enough to jolt society out of a place of power and entitlement, to provide women what they deserve or is it just lip service that the industry is offering to weather the storm?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Citizenship Act: Fundamentally Changing India?
snippet.description:
It's been another tectonic week in India. A week that has seen parliament pass the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Bill 2019 that was signed into law by the President at midnight. The bill has opened two separate fronts in India. In the Northeast, there are concerns that 'outsiders' will take over their tradition, culture and livelihood. These concerns have sparked violent protests, particularly in Assam. On a bigger scale, across the country, not only Opposition parties but also many concerned citizens and even international community have flagged the concern about whether this bill actually runs contrary to the spirit of India's constitution. On The Big Fight, we debate: Is the new Citizenship Act going to fundamentally change India?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | India-Pak Tensions: What Is The Road Ahead For India?
snippet.description:
Wing Commander Abhinandan's return has marked, at least temporarily, a pause in escalating hostilities between India and Pakistan after the Pulwama terror attack and India's air strikes on a Jaish camp in Pakistan. On The Big Fight, we ask the question what are India's options? Former Foreign Secretary Nirupama Rao joining us on the show tonight that India must continue to step up diplomatic pressure, whereas former chief of R&AW A S Dulat believes that the government's policy towards Pakistan must be consistent.

snippet.title: Big Fight with Vikram Chandra | Simultaneous Polls: Aye Or Nay?
snippet.description:
On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we debate whether holding simultaneous elections is a good idea or not. What does 'simultaneous elections' mean? Niti Aayog defines it as follows: It involves the structuring of Indian election cycle in a manner that elections to Lok Sabha and State Assemblies are synchronized together. In such a scenario, a voter would normally cast their vote for electing members of Lok Sabha and State Assembly on a single day and at the same time.
The idea is not new to India and has recently seen favour with both the Prime Minister and the President of the BJP. Will holding simultaneous elections help curb corruption, will it also reduce election expenditure and black money or is the idea too Utopian to be implemented in a democracy like India? Watch this episode as we go through all the nuances of the debate, and send us your feedback on bigfight@ndtv.com

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Life Versus Exams Debate Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
snippet.description:

As life slowly gets back on track, we are also struggling with an ever-increasing number of coronavirus cases. The task of balancing life and livelihood was always the biggest challenge. But a new challenge has now surfaced. As we unlock, should we be holding examinations? Should the lives of millions of students be put at risk?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: High On Growth, Low On Jobs?
snippet.description:
The world is in a state of flux - more so if you are entering the job market. With artificial intelligence, robotics, automation eating away low-skilled, vocational jobs what are millions of people who enter the job market every year going to do? The China model of mass manufacturing and export cannot be replicated anymore in today's world. Are start-ups the way out? Perhaps. But, only if you are a skilled worker. For all the semi-skilled or unskilled workers, the situation is really problematic. Will they depend on government doles for day-to-day existence? The Modi government had placed a lot of emphasis on skill development but the lack of a strong education base and low industry demand is affecting their prospect. The industry, while admitting the changing scenario, is looking for niche skills - nano technologists, experts on robotics, high-end researchers, experienced managers in assembly line production but our education sector has been unable to keep pace with the changing demand. According to an Ernst & Young and FICCI study, over 80 percent of India's engineering graduates and around 90 percent of MBAs are unemployable. It's high time that we completely overhauled our education system. But in the short run, people have to be flexible enough to re-skill themselves and look for work in SMEs or be ready to tread the path of entrepreneurship.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-high-on-growth-low-on-jobs-459792?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Decoding Budget 2018
snippet.description:
After what was the Modi government's last full budget before the 2019 national elections, we debate whether Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has tried to strike a balance between the populism and prudence. The budget announced a major health programme dubbed 'Modicare', details of which are yet to be worked out, while other announcements included schemes for farmers, women and senior citizens. What is the impact that the budget will have on the stakeholders of the Indian economy? Is this a budget poised for growth or a budget aimed for votes?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Decoding The Trump Phenomenon
snippet.description:
Close to two weeks in office and the US President has signed on 18 executive orders and memos already. The President who kept the world media on its toes always managed to leave a hint of what is to come on social media. It isn't a record of any sorts, since his predecessor signed 19 executive orders in the first 12 days of his presidency, but the one thing that perhaps stood out is how this very shrill the political rhetoric that is so markedly Trumpian hasn't faded in the face of the most important political office on the planet. However, there is no denying the fact that most of these 'executive decisions', be it the building of a wall along Mexico or the banning of entry of refugees, are issues he spoke about extensively during his campaign, so of course everything so far is according to 'plan'.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Is The Election Commission's Credibility Still Intact?
snippet.description:
Battleground 2019 has turned out to be a bitter campaign among the contesting parties, but this is an election that will also be remembered for how the Election Commission has conducted itself. The Election Commission has been one of India's most respected institutions but today it finds itself at the heart of scathing criticism. They acted against some political leaders for violating the model code of conduct only after a strong rebuke from the Supreme Court. But after a series of complaints against the PM for violating the model code, PM Modi has got a clean in six cases. Four out of these have seen dissent by one election commissioner. On the show tonight, we ask has the poll panel lost its credibility?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is India Shining Or Whining?
snippet.description:
Among the big questions that a growing economy like India often asks itself is if the country's reputation is going up or down - what is hurting that reputation and what is improving it. This week's Big Fight looks at the things that have happened in recent weeks that have enhanced India's image - the World Bank report on 'Ease of Doing Business' is one - and also others like the attack on Swiss tourists in Agra - that have harmed it. We discuss whether India is shining or do we whine too much about things around us? Do headlines spread negativity or do they help raise awareness about issues that the government must look at?

snippet.title: BJP's Path To 2019: Development Or Polarisation?
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi has reiterated time and again that his government stands for 'Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas' (development without discriminating against anyone). But with the elevation of Hindutva icon Yogi Adityanath as the Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh, will the path of development be junked? Or should we view the leader from Gorakhpur as the new face of development? After the BJP's astounding victory in UP, ministers had harped on the development plan. But with Yogi Adityanath's elevation, opposition leaders and experts raise questions on whether the BJP, along with the development plan, will peddle on soft Hindutva? With over two years to go before the general election in 2019, all eyes are on the newly-elected Chief Minister and the path he will take.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: India's Metros - In Urban Decay?
snippet.description:
There have been a spate of articles lately on the need for a new capital. Why does India need a new capital when it has New Delhi? Because Delhi is saturated in every way possible, say its critics. Its woes include over population, pollution, lack of infrastructure, a polluted river and the list goes on. Do we have the resources to build a capital from scratch or should the capital be "moved"? This brings us to a very contentious point. When one goes through a list of cities to move to, one realizes that the urban decay that infects Delhi is a common feature in cities across India. There isn't a major city in the country that hasn't been confronted by the ills of un-planned development and a lack of basic amenities. Is it time for urban planning to take centre stage? Is it time we demand better facilities from our government? For all this and more join us for this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Constitutional Crisis In Delhi: Arvind Kejriwal-Lt Governor At Loggerheads
snippet.description:
Delhi is witnessing an unprecedented showdown between the Lieutenant Governor and the Chief Minister, resulting in the Chief Minister of Delhi sitting on a dharna - on a sofa. Arvind Kejriwal is trying to get the city to move again, the Lt Governor has his own position and the IAS officers also seem to be on some sort of a strike. In the middle of everything, Delhi is quite not functioning. Amidst this, a demand for Delhi's statehood has been raised and as politics would have it so is the resistance towards it. So, Delhi is facing a constitutional crisis. Whatever be the immediate politics, these are long term issues, long term questions which need to be addressed.

snippet.title: Has India Finally Become A Multi-Sport Nation?
snippet.description:
Has India arrived on the sporting stage? On one hand, India is said to have the best Test cricket team, a claim captain Virat Kohli stands by even after a 1-4 drubbing in the recently-concluded series in England. On the other hand is India's best-ever medal haul at the Asian Games 2018, including many non-conventional sports like sepak takraw and heptathlon. On the Big Fight, we debate whether the recent Test series performance by India is an aberration, with so many athletes bringing in medals in lesser-known sports. Have we finally moved on to becoming a multi-sport nation, focussing on sports other than cricket?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Do high marks ensure success in life?
snippet.description:
It's that time of the year when young students in thousands descend towards universities with their mark sheets in search of college education. With cut offs shooting through the roof, we ask whether marks do actually ensure success in life? Is our education system warped? Do parents also play a crucial role in increasing the pressure on students? Finally, can there be a 'cut off' for finding one's true calling in life? For all this and more, watch this episode of The Big Fight with Dr Annie Koshi, Principal, St. Mary's School; Prof. Dinesh Singh, Former Vice Chancellor, Delhi University; Vineet Gupta, Founder and Trustee Ashoka University; Sanil Sachar Author; Suhel Seth, Managing Partner, Counselage; Biswapati Sarkar, Executive Creative Director, The Viral Fever and Ms. Anu Aga, Chairperson, Thermax Foundation.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Bihar: A PM Modi Vs Tejashwi Yadav Elections?
snippet.description:
Election fever is now at its peak in Bihar. The big guns are out. PM Narendra Modi will have 12 rallies. Tejashwi Yadav is having 12 rallies every day. Meanwhile there is a side script in the NDA with Chirag Paswan. He claims to be with BJP, though BJP claims to be with Nitish Kumar. Rahul Gandhi has also hit the campaign trail, criticising PM Modi. But this time around, one notices a peculiar trend. Gone are the days when Nitish Kumar led the NDA in Bihar. Is this a case where he has had to pillion ride on PM Modi's popularity, that too after 15 years of leading a government? In his speeches, he mentions more about the central government schemes than his own. On The Big Fight, we ask: Has the Bihar election now become about mainly two personalities - Tejashwi Yadav and Narendra Modi?

snippet.title: Should Non-State Groups Like RSS Assist The Army?
snippet.description:
Widely regarded as the ideological big brother of the BJP, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh's clout over the government has been increasing since the BJP government came to power. In a recent controversy, the RSS Chief Mohan Bhagwat appeared to suggest that the organisation could be deployed to defend the nation faster than the army. The RSS later clarified that the organisation was by no means undermining the army but was stating that their disciplined lifestyle offers them an edge when it comes to military action. On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we try and debate the various interpretations of the RSS chief's statement while also looking at the organisations' journey from a cultural one to one that actively engages in politics and governance.

snippet.title: One Nation, One Election: Practical Or Advantage BJP?
snippet.description:
It was supposed to have been the Prime Minister's first big effort at reaching out to the opposition after the new government was sworn in. But, the meeting called to look at the implementation of 'one nation, one election' turned out to be a flop with several opposition parties choosing not to attend. The elections are over, but some would say the simmering discontent within the opposition lingers - others would say regional parties are trying to protect their turf , while still others would say big national parties like the BJP have all to gain at the expense of smaller opposition parties. As we start this episode of The Big Fight, here is a fact that not many may be aware of: The first general elections to the Lok Sabha and all State Legislative Assemblies were held together in 1951-52. That practice continued over three subsequent general elections held in the years - 1957, 1962 and 1967.

snippet.title: Does India Have A 'Rape Problem'?
snippet.description:
Public anger over rapes this week forced the government to take new steps towards addressing the problem.  As one went through graphic details of the assault on children as young as 8 months old, we ask whether India has a 'rape problem'. Is it because of this over arching patriarchal society that we live in, or can it be attributed to the fact that the conviction rate in the case of rape is abysmally low. The government, through an ordinance, hopes to toughen rape laws by raising the minimum punishment for rape from 7 to 10 years. The law will also set a deadline to investigating a rape case. For raping children under 12 years of age, the order allows for the judge to order death penalty to the convict. Will death penalty act as a deterrent to curb these horrific crimes? Experts are of the view that that may prove to be counterproductive as it may endanger the life of the rape victim. With a problem this grave, there are no easy answers here. What is clear however, that women's and children's safety should the priority of the government and stringent preventive action needs to be taken.

snippet.title: What Does Imran Khan As Pakistan PM Mean For India
snippet.description:
In his 'victory speech', Pakistan's new Prime Minister Imran Khan sent a curt message that he should not be portrayed as a "Bollywood villain" in India and that talks are the best way forward for lasting peace between the two biggest countries of the sub-continent. While the emphasis on dialogue with India is a positive signal, security analysts warn against premature celebrations. On The Big Fight, we debate whether Imran Khan's promise of a 'Naya Pakistan' also means renewed hope for Indo-Pak ties. There are genuine concerns in India that for all his vision of peace and prosperity, the cricketer-turned-politician could just end up as a puppet Prime Minister in the hands of the country's miliatry which, in turn, could mean status-quo with India - or worse.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Coronavirus Declared A Pandemic By World Health Organisation
snippet.description:
As the numbers of COVID-19 patients continue to soar around the world, we try and understand what this means for millions of Indians, across different walks of life. This is a special episode of The Big Fight where we look at this almost unbelievable crisis, something that's almost out of a thriller, except this is in real life and quite frightening. And why is that the case? Because COVID-19 is many times more contagious than the seasonal flu, because there is no cure, and because the rate at which the infection is doubling makes this one of the greatest challenges that nations have ever faced. The situation in several Western European countries is bleak and the impact on various parts of our economy could be catastrophic. This is why the World Health Organisation has dubbed this a global pandemic.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: GST - Short Term Pain For Long Term Gain?
snippet.description:
After waiting for more than decade, India has been brought under a unified tax structure - a feat remarkable in such a diverse country where states, more often than not, fight with the centre on issues of federalism. GST will ensure smooth flow of goods between states which were so far subjected to a slew of taxes often holding up trucks and containers ferrying goods causing inordinate delay. While the industry has lauded the single-most biggest tax reform this country has ever undertaken, however, for small traders, service providers who have little or no knowledge of the computer system, confusion is the buzzword. From making extra provision for filing returns to different tax slabs for same goods of different value small manufacturers, business owners are an anxious lot. Will genuine mistakes lead to harassment? What happens if there is problem with the software? Will they end up paying for what is not their fault?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Gujarat Elections - A Battle Of Prestige?
snippet.description:
Gujarat stepped into poll mode today with the first of the two-phase elections in the state. A BJP bastion, the battle for Gujarat has now become a matter of prestige for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and incumbent Congress President Rahul Gandhi. Would the election be a sitter for the BJP since it has been in power in Gujarat since 1998? Will the Patidar factor come into play and split the vote? This high stakes battle is inextricably linked to the success of Rahul Gandhi as a leader; will he prove to be a worthy leader to rescue the Congress out of a state of stupor?

snippet.title: #CashCleanup: Note Worthy Or Not Worthy?
snippet.description:
More than a week has passed since Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced his big-bang strike on black money by banning notes of higher denominations. The aam aadmi had wholeheartedly welcomed the idea initially, but with hardships and inconvenience increasing, people are questioning if there was proper planning before the announcement of this watershed move. The informal sectors have been hit the worse - local shopkeepers, vegetable vendors, small farmers, landless labourers and those working on construction sites. With the cash crunch affecting the economy, will the government show the same alacrity in ensuring that money reaches those who live on the margins of the society? Because if the ground situation doesn't improve, the move might politically backfire for the BJP and political parties like the Aaam Aadmi Party, the Trinomool Congress, the Samajwadi Party are leaving no stone unturned in criticising the government for its frailties in executing the plan. The experts on both side of the political divide are unanimous on one thing - this grand move has to be followed by a crackdown on corruption, more tax reforms and bringing in regulation in the real estate sector. Will the government tread this uncharted waters and walk the talk? Or a year or two from now, people will remember the hardships that they faced the cash crunch that made them anxious with little or no benefit that accrued from this move? Will this go down in history as the big-bang move that will rid India of its black money or will it turn out to be a damp squib?

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/cashcleanup-note-worthy-or-not-worthy-439376?yt

snippet.title: Post Surgical Strikes: The Changing Dynamics Of Indo-Pak Engagement
snippet.description:
Whatever one calls it - a daring move, a game-changer, a paradigm shift - the bottomline is that  Prime Minister Narendra Modi has changed the rules of engagement with Pakistan post the September 29 surgical strikes against terror launch pads across the Line of Control. India received tremendous support from its neighbours especially from SAARC countries, which has pushed Pakistan into a corner. The US, while remaining silent on the strikes, has called on Pakistan to act against terror outfits. So what will Pakistan do now - live in denial about the surgical strikes and blame India for fanning the flame in Balochistan or wait for an opportunity to carry out another terror strike in India through its proxies whom they refer as 'non-state actors'? Or has the surgical strikes forced them to think twice before making another attempt to bleed India? The future of Indo-Pak relations might take an unpredictable turn but PM Modi's message to Pakistan is clear - an attack on India will not go unpunished.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/post-surgical-strikes-the-changing-dynamics-of-indo-pak-engagement-433343?yt

snippet.title: The Right To Die With Dignity
snippet.description:
In a recent verdict, the Supreme Court stated that the Right to Die with Dignity is a fundamental right of every individual, as an extension, it legalised passive euthanasia and approved a 'living will' or an advanced directive for terminally ill patients or those in an incurable vegetative state. The verdict which upheld individual rights was lauded by activists, but not everyone is happy since it poses larger spiritual, philosophical, religious and practical questions. Once made into a law, is this freedom likely to me misused? Will it put undue pressure on the medical fraternity? What about the contentious clause in the government's draft bill that allows for anyone over the age of 16 years to opt for passive euthanasia? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Kashmir on the boil: No lessons learnt?
snippet.description:
The killing of Burhan Wani, a militant has thrown Kashmir again into a cycle of violence with protesters clashing with police and security forces. More than 40 civilians have lost their lives in the ensuing violence and hundreds injured - both civilians and security forces. Some of the civilians injured have lost their eyesight due to pellet injury. Could the loss of lives been avoided had the police been better equipped? Why hasn't the government done anything about upgrading the security forces, providing training for riot control? Is the failure of successive governments to bring a political solution to the Kashmir problem pushing the valley to the edge? Why is there a disconnect and alienation between the political establishment in New Delhi and Kashmiri youth? Are lack of jobs and development forcing the youth to come to streets to vent their anger? Adding to that is the growing concern of radical elements slowly spreading their tentacles. On The Big Fight we discuss: what can be done to bring peace to the region, which has just come out from the throes of a history violent militancy.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Race For Alliances: NDA Leads UPA?
snippet.description:
The biggest battle of India democracy is upon us, election dates have been announced and Battleground 2019 will be the battle between NDA 3.0 and UPA 3.0 and at the moment it seems to be the BJP-led NDA which is leading the race in stitching up alliances. Mahua Moitra, Trinamool spokesperson says that it is battle for the idea of India and if opposition parties don't get their act together there might be no constitution by 2024. KC Tyagi, senior leader of the JDU, says that NDA is a settled alliance and in a key state like Bihar, the BJP-JDU alliance has a definitive edge. Ghanshyam Tiwari of the Samajwadi Party believes that in the most important state of UP, the SP-BSP-RLD grand alliance is set to win and it is for Congress to work out its strategy. On The Big Fight 2019, we ask, who is leading the alliance race.

snippet.title: Are 'Godmen' Above The Law Of The Land?
snippet.description:
The big story that hit the headlines this week was the conviction of self-styled godman Asaram in a case involving the sexual assault of a minor at his ashram in 2013. Asaram Bapu was sentenced to life imprisonment by the Jodhpur court. While reports of sexual assaults continue to pour in from across the country, the ones that have provoked massive outrage were incidents of rapes that occurred in a place of worship. The question that begs to be answered is what gives a "god-person" the right to violate someone and get away with it? As a few "god-persons" freely exercises their authority and influence over unsuspecting devotees, is this behaviour encouraged by the political patronage they receive? Does that make a "god-person" above the law? Should not all men and "god-men" be equal in the eyes of the law? What gives them impunity from the law of the land?

snippet.title: Can PM Modi's Outreach Bring Peace To J&K?
snippet.description:
A monumental decision that has changed the political landscape of Jammu and Kashmir - Article 370 rendered useless, the state being carved into two union territories - Jammu-Kashmir and Ladakh and then, on Thursday, a comprehensive explanation from Prime Minister Narendra Modi on why this has been necessary. As Jammu and Kashmir moves towards normalcy with restrictions being gradually removed, we look at what the Prime Minister said and ask whether the economic outreach that he has proposed has the potential to transform a state that has seen so much suffering for so long.

snippet.title: The Big Fight with Vikram Chandra: Are economic reforms dead?
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi had pledged to herald a new chapter by promising a series of reforms that would bring the economy back on track. Over a year since he took charge, economic reforms are stuck and the consumer-driven domestic economy is falling flat due to low demand. What has gone wrong? Is the Parliament logjam resulting in economic woes? How can the economy be brought back on track? All this and more on this week's episode of 'The Big Fight'.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are India's Minorities Living In Fear?
snippet.description:
When Prime Minister Narendra Modi talked about sabka vishwas, soon after his re-election last month, many believed he was making a real effort to reach out to minorities. That perhaps, this massive mandate could see a change in the way minorities, read Muslims, are looked at and dealt with by the ruling establishment. But this past week, the headlines have been dominated by the haunting video of a 24-year-old Muslim man who was beaten up brutally by a mob in Jharkhand on the suspicion of stealing a motorcycle. Disturbing videos show him being forced to chant slogans of Jai Shri Ram and Jai Hanuman. This year alone there have been 11 hate crimes in India and almost all the victims have been Muslim. Look at Parliament, in the world's largest democracy, where almost 200 million people are Muslims, there are only 27 Muslim MPs and none of them are from the BJP. Do these hate crimes and the disproportionate representation of Muslims mean that minorities have a reason to live in fear or are those fears exaggerated?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Is Press Freedom Under Threat In India?
snippet.description:
On The Big Fight, we talk about the free press. There are a couple of parameters under which we discuss it, first - government's crackdown on the press, secondly the safety of journalists - which is a cause of worry and finally, the need for media to introspect on the quality of news. Why is there an erosion? It should be a fundamental feature of our democracy to be committed to the freedom of press. Free journalism, accurate journalism and journalism that operates without fear from anybody.

snippet.title: Is Technology Making Or Breaking Relationships?
snippet.description:
It has been over 20 years since the first cellular call was made in India. On this week's episode of The Big Fight we discuss how this tiny device has changed our lives. Has the presence of this technological invention altered the way we look at relationships? As much as technology helps bridge distance between loved ones, it also acts like an impediment in our everyday interactions with friends and family. Does technology make us anti-social as we peer into our gadgets isolating those around us? Most of all, can we imagine a life without it? For all this and more, watch The Big Fight.

snippet.title: Should NRIs Be Allowed To Vote Through Proxies?
snippet.description:
Last month, the government took a decision to allow non-resident Indians or NRIs to nominate a proxy to vote in elections. The condition is that both the NRI and the proxy should be from the same constituency and the choice is only confined to elections. While the Parliament is yet to take up the matter and allow it, critics, including former Chief Election Commissioners, have expressed concern that it would violate the model code of secret ballots. If indeed proxy voting is deemed fit to be implemented, then shouldn't the same rule apply to migrants? It should be borne in mind that NRIs already have a legitimate right to vote which was bestowed to them during UPA-II. The only bone of contention was to figure out the modalities. It's true that NRIs have been the flagbearers of Indian culture for decades -- particularly in the US, Gulf countries and in Western Europe, but of late they have been playing an important role in promoting India in their country of residence backed by their growing financial clout. But will proxy voting disrupt the process of voting in India? Will an NRI, notwithstanding their love for their motherland, be able to make judicious choice of selecting the 'right' candidate based on his/her performance without being swayed by party manifestos and ideologies?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Smoke House Delhi: Are We Losing The War Against Pollution?
snippet.description:
There is an air emergency in North India as pollution levels are almost 13 times the safe limit. Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal describes it as a 'gas chamber' and orders the closure of all schools in Delhi till November 5 and distributes pollution masks in the city. In this special edition of The Big Fight, we decided to come out of the studio to discuss how critical the pollution level has become in the capital and why is it essential for us to talk about it and find a solution.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Should Privacy Be A Fundamental Right?
snippet.description:
The ongoing hearing at the Supreme Court on privacy being a fundamental right has reopened a long buried but an important cornerstone of Indian Constitution - should there be reasonable restrictions on privacy of an individual? Though the Constitution doesn't delineate whether privacy should be a fundamental right yet Supreme Court's judgement on the issue in 1954 and 1962 has made it very clear that the right to privacy cannot be absolute. In today's world when the state is perceived as actively trampling into someone's fundamental rights in the name of security and fighting terrorism, is it time for the court to define what constitutes privacy and draw the line?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Battle Of 'Gathbandhans'
snippet.description:
Tonight on The Big Fight Road To 2019, we discuss how the BJP which termed the grand alliance as 'Maha-Milavat' is in fact stitching up a grand alliance of its own, firstly by joining hands with old friend turned foe, now friend again Shiv Sena in Maharashtra and the AIADMK in Tamil Nadu. The question now arises: Is the BJP feeling the heat in lead up to polls or has it accepted the ground reality of coalition compulsions? Joining on the show is Shiv Sena MP Arvind Sawant who says that the alliance will repeat its stellar 2014 show but this time around focus will be on 'equal distribution of power'.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: 6 Big Questions After Demonetisation
snippet.description:
It has been more than a fortnight since the ban on old 500 and 1,000 rupee notes was announced. For the common man, it meant inconvenience, for small traders it meant being unable to buy stocks, for daily labourers it translated into a nightmare, farmers were left stranded with their crops unable to pay for the fertilisers and there were those who had to run from pillar to the post to arrange money for hospitalisation. But all this inconvenience would be washed away only if the the 'big fishes' or 'fat cats' - those with black money - be caught and appropriate punishment meted out. Otherwise it will be the long queues, the hardships and the loss of business and jobs that will remain an indelible memory. To this end, we ask six crucial questions that every citizen should think about.

snippet.title: 2019: One Nation, One Poll?
snippet.description:
PM Modi and the Niti Aayog have been pushing the case for simultaneous elections to be held all across the country in a bid to overhaul the electoral system and to save the huge amount of money that is spent in conducting elections. According to the Niti Aayog, on an average there are five to seven elections annually which leads to disruption of governance and loss of a great amount of time and money. While many agree that conducting Lok Sabha and State assembly elections simultaneously will be a good idea, no clear road map as to how this concept should be implemented has come up. The consultations conducted by Law Commission this past week saw parties divided over the issue. On The Big Fight, we debate whether 'One nation, one poll' is indeed a good idea and whether it will prove to be PM Modi's political masterstroke for 2019.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: BJP's Winning Spree - Is It The Modi Factor?
snippet.description:
Post note ban, the BJP is on a winning spree. Barring the setback in Punjab, BJP has won handsomely in UP and Uttarakhand, formed government in Goa and Manipur, became the largest party in Maharashtra's municipal and Zilla Parishad polls, dislodged Congress from being the main opposition in Odisha's municipal and panchayat polls, and trounced AAP in Delhi civic polls. What explains BJP's winning spree? Is it the Modi factor or is it due to the fact that there is no viable opposition at the national level?

The second and the most important issue is the discourse and the focus of the governance. While Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks about development, governance, fight against corruption and black money, it's the fringe on the ground which is at times overshadowing PM Modi's development agenda. Is there a subtext to the path this government is following?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Backlash Against France: Islamophobia vs 'Islamofascism'
snippet.description:
There is a global debate raging around two words - Islamophobia and Islamofascism. India has taken an unprecedented position in favour of France. New Delhi has openly backed French President Emmanuel Macron calling the personal attacks on him deplorable. Meanwhile, many people say that there is a duplicity in the argument of Islamic countries. They are united against France but silent on China's Muslim persecution. Why? On the Big Fight, we look at Islamic backlash against France and the debate over it. And we decode India's unprecedented stand.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Start-Ups - Unleashing India's Entrepreneurial Energy
snippet.description:
Of late, Indian start-ups have been grabbing headlines for all the wrong reasons - layoffs, sexual harassment, a dip in funding, closures - to name a few. So, is the start-up bubble about to burst? Is it going the 'dotcom' way or are we being too cynical towards a sector where historically the failure rate is at 90 per cent? There are issues that afflict the start-ups but with jobs drying up in traditional sectors, start-ups are the best bet to drive the job market. Even if the venture fails, people working in start-ups are regarded highly by corporate when it come to hiring. Should the government then provide extra fillip to start-ups like easy exit in case of failures?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Does Our History Need Correcting?
snippet.description:
The government under the leadership of the Culture Minister Mahesh Sharma has constituted a committee to rewrite India's ancient history. It is the government's intention to trace the history of the country back to 12,000 years and 'fill the gaps' created by earlier historians who the government feels, may have carried a bias. On the show, we debate whether history can be written without an ideological tilt? Will this attempt to 'rewrite' history by the government, ignore facts while supporting a certain stand point? Should the government get involved in how the history of a country is written or should this be the exclusive mandate of social scientists and academicians? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight.

snippet.title: The Dawn Of The Age Of Artificial Intelligence
snippet.description:
It is something that impacts our day-to-day life, as we search for traffic free routes on our phones, or play a game of chess 'with the computer' or search for the coolest restaurant to visit - but how often do we actually think about 'artificial intelligence'. On this special episode of The Big Fight, we look at the role that artificial intelligence will play in our future, the sectors that will rely on it heavily, what the government will need to do to regulate it and if there should be laws to govern AI? Is there much more to AI than what is depicted in popular culture? Should we guard against the possible misuse of this artificial intelligence or take it as an ally in civilizational development? For all this and more watch this week's episode of The Big Fight and share your thoughts with us on bigfight@ndtv.com

snippet.title: The Big Fight | NRC: Anti-Illegal Immigrants Or Anti-Muslim?
snippet.description:
This week, the Supreme Court extended by one month its deadline for a National Citizen's Register to be completed by the government in Assam. It will now have to be done by August 31. The exercise, which is taking place only in Assam for now, was put on the fast track by the top court in 2015. It aims to weed out illegal immigrants and ensure only genuine Indian citizens reside in the state. But the process of the NRC has been deeply flawed  from the start. The basic premise of putting the onus on individuals to prove their citizenship has been problematic. People have to produce documents to show that they are genuine citizens and not everyone has that paperwork. There are over four million people who have currently been excluded from the list and they have a right to appeal to foreigner tribunals and then the courts. If all these options fail, they can be jailed in detention centres, but some of the examples of those excluded has been jarring - like a former armyman who is currently out on bail after being excluded from the list. Critics say the BJP has decided to make Muslims the real target. They point out that it is no coincidence that the government has a bill ready which will exclude only Muslim immigrants from neighbouring countries to seek refuge in India. The BJP denies this; the government says the exercise is only aimed at illegals. But the story is no longer about Assam. Home Minister Amit Shah has declared in parliament that illegal immigrants from every inch of India will be thrown out. So what is the NRC really about? Is it anti-illegal immigrants or anti-Muslim?

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Are Indians racist?
snippet.description:
Though we profess to believe in the mantra of universal brotherhood yet there is no denying of the fact that there is a deep-seated bias or prejudice against communities different from our own. Whether it's the taunt that people from North East hear in Delhi or police hostility towards Africans nationals living in India, these incidents leave a long scar in our collective morality and begs the question whether such incidents are mere anomalies or is there indeed a deep bias in us when it comes to “foreigners”? There are of course cases where certain foreigners are given "preferential treatment" based possibly on the colour of their skin. Do we suffer from a colonial hangover? Or can the problem be traced back to the Vedic 'varna system'? Is education the best way to rid our society of such prejudices? We debate on The Big Fight.

localized.title: The Big Fight: Are Indians racist?
localized.description:
Though we profess to believe in the mantra of universal brotherhood yet there is no denying of the fact that there is a deep-seated bias or prejudice against communities different from our own. Whether it's the taunt that people from North East hear in Delhi or police hostility towards Africans nationals living in India, these incidents leave a long scar in our collective morality and begs the question whether such incidents are mere anomalies or is there indeed a deep bias in us when it comes to “foreigners”? There are of course cases where certain foreigners are given "preferential treatment" based possibly on the colour of their skin. Do we suffer from a colonial hangover? Or can the problem be traced back to the Vedic 'varna system'? Is education the best way to rid our society of such prejudices? We debate on The Big Fight.

Watch full video: http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-big-fight/the-big-fight-are-indians-racist/403650?yt

snippet.title: The Big Fight | How Will Citizenship And Quota Bills Impact BJP's Prospects In 2019 Polls?
snippet.description:
Tonight on the Big Fight - Road to 2019, we discuss the implications of the two big bills passed by parliament - the 10 per cent quota bill for the general category and the citizenship amendment bill passed by Lok Sabha. Former Assam chief minister and ex-BJP ally AGP's Founding President Prafulla Mahanta says that there is massive unrest against the citizenship bill and it will have massive impact across the north-east. On the show, we ask, how will these two bills impact BJP's prospects in 2019 elections and eventually the political situation of India?

snippet.title: Poll Of Exit Polls Shows Hung House In Karnataka, BJP Largest
snippet.description:
Karnataka could return a split verdict with the BJP as the single largest party and former Prime Minister HD Deve Gowda a kingmaker, an aggregate of nine exit polls show. But the exit polls were deeply divided on the outcome -- five of them predicting that the BJP will be the single largest party. Two of them suggested that there is an outside chance that the party will gain majority.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Holy Cow, Unholy Politics?
snippet.description:
The centre has imposed a ban on sale of cattle for slaughter under the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act. This has led to a series of protests in states of Kerala, West Bengal, Meghalaya and Nagaland where beef consumption is not deemed illegal. Can the centre impose such a ban? Does it undermine the federal structure of the country? In most states, there is already a ban on cow slaughter. So what necessitated the ban? Is it a diversionary tactic from issues like decline in jobs and a dip in GDP growth? Or is cow being used as an emotive issue for electoral purpose?

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Akhilesh Yadav-Mayawati Tie Up: The Perfect Alliance?
snippet.description:
Tonight on the Road to 2019, we discuss the political implications of the Mayawati-Akhilesh Yadav alliance in Uttar Pradesh. We break down the numbers and see why Mayawati says this alliance will give BJP sleepless nights, and even by doing projections based on the 'Modi Wave' election of 2014 this alliance can wipe out BJP's then 71 seats almost by half. Also on the show tonight, we talk exclusively to former Delhi chief minister Sheila Dikshit who is back as Delhi Congress chief on Congress prospects in Delhi, alliance with AAP and the controversy around Jagdish Tytler being seen in front row at the event where she returned to active Delhi politics.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: A New Wave Of Communalism
snippet.description:
It seems, at least in the domain of mass media, that we are living in an age of binaries. Today in India, where sane voices taking middle ground on the issues of communalism, terrorism and nationalism are being drowned in the cacophony of social media trolls, the discourse is increasingly being shaped by extreme voices. This was more evident in the recent events that rattled the nation - from the attack on Amarnath pilgrims in Kashmir to the communal riots in Basirhat, West Bengal. While the right-wing accused the "liberals", "Leftists", civil society and mainstream media of selective outrage, the "liberals" responded by blaming the right-wing brigade of stoking the communal fire, of deliberately blaming the minority community and posting fake news to justify the cause. Are we entering a new era of polarisation? Is there a justification in the charge labelled by right-wingers against civil society and liberals of selective outrage? Or are foot-soldiers of communalism taking it too far with communal elements running amok?

snippet.title: Urban flooding: A 'sinking' reality?
snippet.description:
You must have seen these images. People fishing in IT hub Bengaluru when it was flooded, India's Millennium City Gurgaon looking like Venice with flooded streets sans Gondolas, people stranded in Mumbai with rail services disrupted due to rains and cars floating in an inundated Hyderabad. The picture is same everywhere - urban India can't cope up with monsoon rains. Why is it that a country which aspires to be superpower lacks properly planned cities? Why is that in every city the 'natural drainage' system has been destroyed? Why is that every inch of open space, storm-water drains have been encroached upon by illegal construction? Why is it that environmental laws have been bypassed by 'Builder-Babu-Neta' nexus? Are our cities heading towards an urban chaos? Can we as citizens hope to see political will and consensus over 'fixing' our cities?

Watch full show: http://www.ndtv.com/video/news/the-big-fight/urban-flooding-a-sinking-reality-429963?yt

snippet.title: Maldives Crisis: A Mega Battle For Regional Influence?
snippet.description:
The tiny island nation of Maldives made waves across the world this week after President Abdulla Yameen declared a state emergency and took political prisoners including members of the judiciary who took him on over the prosecution of political opponents. The Supreme Court of Maldives appealed for India to step in to resolve this situation but India is yet to respond to the crisis. Is it time for New Delhi to step up its diplomacy to curb the increasing Chinese influence in India's neighbourhood? Is India losing its charm as the superpower in the Indian ocean as China eyes trade and military networks in the region? Is it wise to follow the 'wait and watch' policy or is it time for swift overt action? On this week's episode of The Big Fight, we speak to experts from the field of foreign policy to help us decode this strategic conundrum.

snippet.title: The Big Fight | Tanishq Withdrawal: Have We Normalised Bigotry?
snippet.description:
The problem we face most is what to accept as reality and what not to. So the easiest way to decode this is to define it as good reality and bad reality. First the good reality: inter-faith marriages and inter-faith harmony exists in this country. It is a fact. But then there is the bad reality as well. Communal clashes and religious conflict too is a reality in this country. But what do we want to celebrate is going to define our character. Will we celebrate our unity or our differences? The Tanishq advertisement withdrawal has kick-started this very basic and fundamental debate. Have we all started celebrating the bad reality where we celebrate and accept bigotry and communal differences?

snippet.title: Maharashtra Stunner: Phir Ek Baar, Fadnavis Sarkaar | The Big Fight
snippet.description:
In a move that has stunned everyone, BJP's Devendra Fadnavis quietly took oath as Maharashtra Chief Minister in the early hours this morning with the NCP's Ajit Pawar beside him taking oath as his deputy. Just 12 hours earlier, NCP chief Sharad Pawar had said Shiv Sena's Udhhav Thackeray was the choice for the chief minister's post after a meeting of the Congress-NCP and the Sena. On The Big Fight today, we look at all the twists and turns that are taking place in the political spectrum of Maharashtra.

snippet.title: The Big Fight: Will Anti-Lynching Law Work?
snippet.description:
In the wake of a number of incidents mob violence, the Supreme Court has suggested that a  new law be enacted specifically to deal with the "new normal" of lynchings. But doubts remain about the efficacy of the proposed solution. On The Big Fight, we debate whether a new law is the solution. The judgment places the onus on the law and order machinery to prevent and punish lynchings but can a new law work if there is lack of political will to tackle the lynch mobs?
